Description: Massachusetts Financial Services Co. agreed to pay $225 million to settle allegations that it violated federal securities laws by allowing widespread market timing trading in certain of its mutual funds in contravention of those funds' public disclosures.

Massachusetts Financial Services Company agreed to pay $50 million to settle allegations that it failed to adequately disclose the specifics of its shelf-space arrangements with brokerage firms and the conflicts created by those arrangements.

Company: Sun Life Assurance Company of Canada (U.S.)
Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
NAICS Translation: 52411: Direct Life, Health, and Medical Insurance Carriers
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: To resolve market timing allegations brought by the New York Attorney General, MFS agreed to pay $175 million in restitution to injured investors, cut its management fees by an estimated $125 million over the next five years and pay a penalty of $50 million.
Sun Life agreed to pay $3.2 million to settle multistate litigation regarding its use of the Social Security Administration's Death Master File.
Info Source: Sun Life Insurance Company Agrees to Change Its Use of the Death Master File, States News Service, November 13, 2014 (via Nexis).
